``Dr. Feelgood'' (Elektra) _ Motley Crue
Rx for feeling good? Send for Motley Crue's ``Dr. Feelgood.'' Produced by Bob Rock, who just wrapped the Cult's ``Sonic Temple,'' the fifth album from heavy metal vaudevillians Motley Crue has something for everyone. If you're mulling over the current political disarray in the world, there's ``Time to Change,'' the musically sappy but lyrically stinging closing ballad. If you like things a bit more playful, there's ``Sticky Sweet,'' ``She Goes Down'' and ``Same Old Situation (S.O.S.).'' But the wittiest, most Aerosmith-like of these is the down-in-the-bayou groove of ``Slice of Your Pie,'' a two-part tale of lead singer Vince Neil leering at a female passer-by, then getting her where he wants her via the closing grind, a steal from the Beatles' ``I Want You (She's So Heavy).'' Numbers such as the barroom stomp of ``Rattlesnake Shake'' and the near-speed metal of ``Kickstart My Heart'' show off the new and improved musicianship of guitarist Mick Mars and bassist Nikki Sixx, who both leave behind most of the usual metal riffs they used in 1987's ``Girls, Girls, Girls.'' Standouts are the title track, a tale of urban blight as seen through a drug kingpin's rise and fall, and the dark ``Without You,'' written by Sixx for drummer Tommy Lee and his actress wife, Heather Locklear. The latter, praising monogamy, is a nice break from the relentless barrage of the sex songs on ``Feelgood,'' and the mushiness of recent power ballads such as Warrant's ``Heaven.'' If you want Aerosmith, buy their latest, ``Pump,'' but the closest thing on the Motley's record is ``Don't Go Away Mad (Just Go Away).'' It's a breakup song with a smart attitude, despite the ending that strains to use the cute title.
